Spatial Transcriptomics: From Data Acquisition to Interpretation - Course Outline Chapter 1 Introduction 1.1 Course Schedule

Spatial Transcriptomics: From Data Acquisition to Interpretation - Course Outline Dr. Taru Dutt November 25th - 29th Chapter 1 Introduction Welcome to the course outline for “Spatial Transcriptomics: From Data Acquisition to Interpretation.” This outline provides an overview of each day’s topics and objectives for the 5-day intensive course. 1.1 Course Schedule Day 1: Introduction and Overview of Spatial Transcriptomics Day 2: Data Quality Control and Normalization Day 3: Feature Identification and Data Merging Day 4: Cell-Cell Interaction and Spatial Pattern Analysis Day 5: Data Visualization, Interpretation, and Reporting Each chapter in this outline corresponds to a day in the course and details the planned sessions and activities.

Chapter 2 Day 1: Introduction and Overview of Spatial Transcriptomics 2.1 Morning Session (9:00 am - 12:00 pm) 2.2 Afternoon Session (1:00 pm - 5:00 pm)

Chapter 2 Day 1: Introduction and Overview of Spatial Transcriptomics 2.1 Morning Session (9:00 am - 12:00 pm) Course Introduction and Objectives: Overview of the course structure and objectives, introduction to spatial transcriptomics, and setting the context. Overview of Spatial Transcriptomics Technology: Historical background, comparison with traditional transcriptomics, and introduction to the Visium platform. 2.2 Afternoon Session (1:00 pm - 5:00 pm) Experimental Design and Hypothesis-Driven Research: Crafting research questions, experimental design, and best practices for spatial transcriptomics. Hands-On with Space Ranger: Introduction to data acquisition using Space Ranger, aligning gene expression with tissue morphology, and generating outputs.
day-2-data-quality-control-and-normalization.html
Chapter 3 Day 2: Data Quality Control and Normalization 3.1 Morning Session (9:00 am - 12:00 pm) 3.2 Afternoon Session (1:00 pm - 5:00 pm)

Chapter 3 Day 2: Data Quality Control and Normalization 3.1 Morning Session (9:00 am - 12:00 pm) Introduction to Quality Control (QC): Understanding key QC metrics, visual QC assessment, and filtering data for reliability. Data Normalization Techniques: Log-normalization, SCTransform, CLR normalization, and dealing with batch effects. 3.2 Afternoon Session (1:00 pm - 5:00 pm) Advanced Normalization and Integration: Normalization tailored for spatial transcriptomics and integration with single-cell RNA-seq data. Hands-On Session: Practical QC filtering and normalization techniques on provided datasets, visualization, and interpretation.
day-3-feature-identification-and-data-merging.html
Chapter 4 Day 3: Feature Identification and Data Merging 4.1 Morning Session (9:00 am - 12:00 pm) 4.2 Afternoon Session (1:00 pm - 5:00 pm)

Chapter 4 Day 3: Feature Identification and Data Merging 4.1 Morning Session (9:00 am - 12:00 pm) Identifying Spatially Variable Features: Techniques for feature selection and identifying spatially variable genes. 4.2 Afternoon Session (1:00 pm - 5:00 pm) Data Merging and Integration: Strategies for combining datasets, handling batch effects, and practical session on data integration. Clustering and Cell-Type Identification: Overview of clustering methods and cell-type identification for spatial transcriptomics data.
day-4-cell-cell-interaction-and-spatial-pattern-analysis.html
Chapter 5 Day 4: Cell-Cell Interaction and Spatial Pattern Analysis 5.1 Morning Session (9:00 am - 12:00 pm) 5.2 Afternoon Session (1:00 pm - 5:00 pm)

Chapter 5 Day 4: Cell-Cell Interaction and Spatial Pattern Analysis 5.1 Morning Session (9:00 am - 12:00 pm) Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis: Importance of cell-cell interactions in tissue function, techniques for analysis, and overview of tools. 5.2 Afternoon Session (1:00 pm - 5:00 pm) Hypothesis-Driven Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis: Designing cell-cell interaction analyses based on specific hypotheses. Hands-On Session: Applying tools for cell-cell interaction analysis, generating reports, and interpreting findings.
day-5-data-visualization-interpretation-and-reporting.html
Chapter 6 Day 5: Data Visualization, Interpretation, and Reporting 6.1 Morning Session (9:00 am - 12:00 pm) 6.2 Afternoon Session (1:00 pm - 5:00 pm)

Chapter 6 Day 5: Data Visualization, Interpretation, and Reporting 6.1 Morning Session (9:00 am - 12:00 pm) Data Visualization Techniques: Generating high-quality visualizations, spatial heatmaps, and cell type maps. Biological Interpretation: Linking spatial data to functional annotations and interpreting biological findings. 6.2 Afternoon Session (1:00 pm - 5:00 pm) Reporting and Communicating Results: Structuring reports for spatial transcriptomics studies, creating publication-ready figures, and discussing complex spatial patterns. Final Project and Feedback: Student presentations, group feedback, and a course recap.

Chapter 7 Hello bookdown All chapters start with a first-level heading followed by your chapter title, like the line above. There should be only one first-level heading (#) per .Rmd file. 7.1 A section All chapter sections start with a second-level (##) or higher heading followed by your section title, like the sections above and below here. You can have as many as you want within a chapter. An unnumbered section Chapters and sections are numbered by default. To un-number a heading, add a {.unnumbered} or the shorter {-} at the end of the heading, like in this section.

Chapter 8 Cross-references 8.1 Chapters and sub-chapters 8.2 Captioned figures and tables

Chapter 8 Cross-references Cross-references make it easier for your readers to find and link to elements in your book. 8.1 Chapters and sub-chapters There are two steps to cross-reference any heading: Label the heading: # Hello world {#nice-label}. Leave the label off if you like the automated heading generated based on your heading title: for example, # Hello world = # Hello world {#hello-world}. To label an un-numbered heading, use: # Hello world {-#nice-label} or {# Hello world .unnumbered}. Next, reference the labeled heading anywhere in the text using \@ref(nice-label); for example, please see Chapter 8. If you prefer text as the link instead of a numbered reference use: any text you want can go here. 8.2 Captioned figures and tables Figures and tables with captions can also be cross-referenced from elsewhere in your book using \@ref(fig:chunk-label) and \@ref(tab:chunk-label), respectively. See Figure 8.1. par(mar = c(4, 4, .1, .1)) plot(pressure, type = 'b', pch = 19) Figure 8.1: Here is a nice figure! Don’t miss Table 8.1. knitr::kable( head(pressure, 10), caption = 'Here is a nice table!', booktabs = TRUE ) Table 8.1: Here is a nice table! temperature pressure 0 0.0002 20 0.0012 40 0.0060 60 0.0300 80 0.0900 100 0.2700 120 0.7500 140 1.8500 160 4.2000 180 8.8000
parts.html
Chapter 9 Parts

Chapter 9 Parts You can add parts to organize one or more book chapters together. Parts can be inserted at the top of an .Rmd file, before the first-level chapter heading in that same file. Add a numbered part: # (PART) Act one {-} (followed by # A chapter) Add an unnumbered part: # (PART\*) Act one {-} (followed by # A chapter) Add an appendix as a special kind of un-numbered part: # (APPENDIX) Other stuff {-} (followed by # A chapter). Chapters in an appendix are prepended with letters instead of numbers.

Chapter 12 Sharing your book 12.1 Publishing 12.2 404 pages 12.3 Metadata for sharing

Chapter 12 Sharing your book 12.1 Publishing HTML books can be published online, see: https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/publishing.html 12.2 404 pages By default, users will be directed to a 404 page if they try to access a webpage that cannot be found. If you’d like to customize your 404 page instead of using the default, you may add either a _404.Rmd or _404.md file to your project root and use code and/or Markdown syntax. 12.3 Metadata for sharing Bookdown HTML books will provide HTML metadata for social sharing on platforms like Twitter, Facebook, and LinkedIn, using information you provide in the index.Rmd YAML. To setup, set the url for your book and the path to your cover-image file. Your book’s title and description are also used. This gitbook uses the same social sharing data across all chapters in your book- all links shared will look the same. Specify your book’s source repository on GitHub using the edit key under the configuration options in the _output.yml file, which allows users to suggest an edit by linking to a chapter’s source file. Read more about the features of this output format here: https://pkgs.rstudio.com/bookdown/reference/gitbook.html Or use: ?bookdown::gitbook
